comments.commentBody: The Affordable Care Act will not be fully implemented in states that refuse to expand Medicaid, including my own.  Lots of people, while poor, will not qualify for Medicaid, and won't be able to take advantage of federal subsidies for insurance.
Yes. Thanks. We're aware of that.

Another spring day in Oklahoma.

Look: Oklahoma is prone to violent spring weather. It is the nature of living there just as earthquakes are a fact of life in California. Global warming effect? Maybe, maybe not. If the same size tornado shows up next month, then we should have a conversation on global warming. Otherwise, it can be explained as an ordinary event.

They had a more severe tornado in May 1999 in the same area.
This is such a tragedy. We will continue to pray for everyone affected by this disaster.... "Adrick Alexander Ingram"

I forgot to say in my previous comment, that since there are no gods,  all the prayers in the world won't help.  But we should all donate to Red Cross or another organization to help the folks in Oklahoma.
What do you think "we" did to "provoke" Mother Mature (sic) to send us this tornado?  Are you serious?

Amen.  Of course, there hasn't been a NYT comments section free of Republican-bashing since Hope and Change mesmerized the populace-- no matter the article's subject matter.  Although there have been many worse tornadoes over Tornado Alley's recorded history, the typical lib 's predictable knee-jerk reaction to this tragedy will be to rail against the Keystone pipeline, for more income redistribution, for the creation of even more government regulation and bureaucracy.  Like a carbon tax will matter to the perfect solar convection oven that is Tornado Alley...
"At some point, we need to consider not provoking her any further." Agreed. Now might be a good time.
Yes. Thanks. We're aware of that.

"If the same size tornado shows up next month, then we should have a conversation on global warming. Otherwise, it can be explained as an ordinary event."

Oklahoma has never experienced a tornado this size in recorded history. Neither has the USA.

The 1999 Oklahoma tornado (which I rode through) produced the highest wind speed ever recorded on planet Earth.

So let's talk.

No, we're through talking. Let's try the greedy deniers, like Inhofe, Limbaugh and the people at Fox for capital murder, and sentence them Oklahoma-style.

This is complete rubbish in light of the fact that Germany is underrepresented in any EU decision-making institution (e.g. the European Parliament, the European Council, the ECB, the European Commission, the European Court of Justice).
Always and every time, send MONEY. Canned food is just a hassle, as is used clothing and teddy bears. They can buy all that stuff 20 blocks away. Send MONEY.
Always and every time, send MONEY. Canned food is just a hassle, as is used clothing and teddy bears. They can buy all that stuff 20 blocks away. Send MONEY.

To nostone, who wrote:

" . . . you don't have the right to judge them."

If they have the right to fire this teacher, we have the right to judge them.

nostone:  I don't have the right to judge them?  MY judgments don't cost people their jobs. Unfortunately the Catholic church is all about judgment, followed by damnation.  And this despite Christ's dictum "Judge not lest yee be judged."
Jesus did not create the Church of Rome.  That is a construct of man.

So an anonymous letter sent by an intolerant coward carries more weight with the Diocese of Columbus than a valued teacher who's been on their payroll for nearly two decades.  How did they explain this to her students?  Or did they bother to explain it at all?  I suspect that if Jesus were to walk this earth today, preaching a gospel of love and acceptance, He too would be spurned by the church He created.

So Apple is claiming the US Tax codes made them stash all their money in tax havens overseas! Reminds me of Mr. Romney's claim that his very low tax rates were a result of tax codes. Neither Apple or Romney will acknowledge the role of their own lobbyists in writing those beneficial tax codes.

Yes, it is time to reform the tax codes, but politicians in Washington would prefer to bash low level IRS employees for trying to enforce those byzantine codes. That "scandal" will keep our eyes off the real scandal epitomized by Romney and Apple.

Hello witschi, rice is a staple in China in a way it is not in the U.S. therefore testing this food item eaten every day, sometimes two or three times a day, by hundreds of millions of people, is especially relevant here. It's unclear whether there is a comparable measure for rice in the U.S. but you can start here: http://www.atsdr.cdc.gov/phs/phs.asp?id=46&tid=15
This site offers some figures for "acceptable" levels of cadmium in drinking water and invites queries for those interested in finding out more.
Overall, toxic substances in the environment and in the food chain are a problem that threatens animal and human health everywhere, including China.
Best,
Didi
It would have been interesting if the article had stated the Cadmium limit in rice sold in the US.  For all I know, twice the Chinese limit may be acceptable for sale here.
China....heaven help us all.

Yes, MLL, tHATS exactly wHAT I'm slurring! Heh Heh Heh

Howie YBOQ
We already had that hat-trick with Blindauer, so now we have a grand slam!

You're right, five, as I was unwise with eyes unable to see Patrick Blindauer, and I hope he forgives me for omitting him from the "Patrick" XWDP constructing society?

Howie

What we have this Tuesday night is still another "Patrick" that takes his rightful place along side the greatly esteemed Messieurs Berry and Merrell...TRIAD on for size!

Howie TBOQ

Ross Douthat is on a similar track, he and Brooks must be comparing talking points. Douthat writes that the increase in the suicide rate especially amongst men over 50 is also as a result of these cultural shifts. It is jobs, it is income distribution and it is public safety nets David. People who have steady jobs that pay at a minimum a living wage have a good start on not only a healthy self esteem but in providing for themselves and their families. Living life with one's nose pressed against the glass and watching the upper ten percent with their Mac-mansions, luxury cars, vacation houses, stock portfolios and offshore bank accounts and gold plated health care whilst earning $7 a hour or living on unemployment does not make for a healthy society.

Mancuroc, great point. Brooks, as usual, points out the cultural decline across all levels of society, and particularly the poor. Let's have a country where the minimum wage is a living wage. Then, we as taxpayers, don't have to pay for Walmart's employees who are on public welfare and public healthcare. Brooks, if you read this, it's the economy stupid. Let's start by removing tax breaks for companies who shift jobs overseas and tax products made overseas that are subsidized by their government.

Economy determines the culture? So why does wealth in the hands of musicians result in vulgar lyrics in 2013, while wealth in the hands of musicians in the 1930's resulted in a musical culture with clean lyrics?

I knew it! I was waiting for Brooks to subtly skew his conclusion his way and he didn't disappoint.

He argues that our problems aren't economic, they are cultural, and therefore there's no point in tackling them by economic means. Earth to Brooks: the economy strongly determines the culture. That is why we now talk of a culture of greed, the degree of which represents a tectonic shift in our culture and which has itself undermined community bonds.

Medicare and Medicaid spend over 50% of our healthcare. For-profit insurers are now less than 30%. (The balance is non-profits and HMOS)

Before Medicare, we has 98% private coverage, the uninsured poor and elderly were treated in charity hospitals. Healthcare was 5.8%.

SOMEHOW -- we're not sure how -- private insurers have managed to triple our healthcare costs ... while losing 70% of their market share. Diabolical, eh?
Well, with Medicare having a 20% waste, fraud and abuse record, expanding that will crash the ecomony, big time.  Get real.
Coolhunter –  you missed the part where the Feds have gone after Medicare & Medicaid fraud. Seems Rick Scott, GOP gov of Florida, was one of the perpetrators; his company paid $1.7 BILLION in fines.

This is a despicable fighting retreat by Republicans on health care reform to cause as many casualties as possible, more people without insurance, more personal bankruptcies, more hospitals with uncompensated care, more expensive emergency interventions and unnecessary deaths from untreated chronic conditions.

But their miscalculation is that they lack their normal constituency for their ideological position, other than those ignorant of the law. The providers, insurers, parents with children under 26, those with low incomes, those denied insurance for health reasons, those who can't get real insurance through their employer and anyone else not on Medicare have something to gain from self-funded Obama Care.

Of course, many feel comfortable with their current employer provided insurance, that is until they are unemployed, something that happens to an alarming number of people past 50 these days.

Many Americans would like to see universal Medicare at far lower cost like most other developed countries. But when the for-profit health care industry approaches 20% of total GDP, this will never happen through national legislative fiat. But it may happen incrementally through the competitive mechanism of the ACA, which favors lowest cost, highest quality, non-profit medicine already available in a few markets.
Nothing illegal here because they wrote the laws.
What's wrong with digging a basement in Oklahoma? There's no water table. We did that in Iowa, and it can save your life. The pioneers dug root cellars and they doubled as storm cellars.
